messages.author: tonyg
messages.text: While the method name seems fine and the comment is accurate, the comment seems to assume too much about what WebKit is doing with this time. Maybe we should say something more general like "Indicate the user perceived start time of the navigation."

messages.author: tonyg
messages.text: In chromium style we don't omit the param names even when they are trivial.

messages.author: James Simonsen
messages.text:
On 2012/01/25 22:18:09, tonyg wrote:
> While the method name seems fine and the comment is accurate, the comment seems
> to assume too much about what WebKit is doing with this time. Maybe we should
> say something more general like "Indicate the user perceived start time of the
> navigation."

Done.

I'm a little leery of leaving it generic though. We're trying to follow a tight definition in Navigation Timing. If someone comes along and sees this, they'll be inclined to pass in some other value they think better approximates "navigation start."

messages.author: James Simonsen
messages.text:
On 2012/01/25 22:18:09, tonyg wrote:
> In chromium style we don't omit the param names even when they are trivial.

Done.

messages.author: darin
messages.text: why are details of cross-origin navigations leaking outside of the content module?  this seems like something that chrome shouldn't have to know anything about.

messages.author: James Simonsen
messages.text:
On 2012/01/26 05:06:47, darin wrote:
> why are details of cross-origin navigations leaking outside of the content
> module?  this seems like something that chrome shouldn't have to know anything
> about.

Hmm. It's unfortunate this is exported. It's not used outside the content module. There's a TODO(joi) at the top of the file to make it invisible to Chrome.

I've updated the description to be more generic though.
